author: By Andrew Keh and Pete Kiehart
title: How Indigenous Athletes Are Reclaiming Lacrosse
description: The Haudenosaunee Nationals lacrosse teams have a big ambition: competing in the 2028 Olympic Games in Los Angeles.
content: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Brendan Bomberry’s voice was growing louder, his words spilling out faster and faster as he unleashed a profanity-laced pep talk on his teammates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Emily Schmall
title: Bangladesh Seeks I.M.F. Loan as Inflation Rocks South Asia
description: As trade deficits widen, governments in the region struggle to import increasingly expensive diesel, gasoline and cooking gas.
content: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Just a week after introducing scheduled power outages in response to the soaring cost of fuel in Bangladesh, the government said it was seeking help from the International Monetary Fund, joining two other nations in South Asia to do so in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: So Much Tech. So Few Winners.
description: Technology is everything. Why are there hardly any blockbuster tech companies of the smartphone age?
content: We know that in the 15 years since the iPhone went on sale, technology has seeped into every crevice of our lives. Tech has reshaped politics, industries, leisure time, culture and people’s relationships to one another — for better and for worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: Mario Draghi’s Fall Is a Triumph of Democracy, Not a Threat to It
description: No voter ever cast a ballot for him.
content: Mario Draghi, who last week submitted his resignation as prime minister of Italy, has an extraordinary résumé for a contemporary statesman: executive director of the World Bank in the 1980s; director general of the Italian Treasury in the 1990s; governor of the Bank of Italy in the 2000s; and president of the European Central Bank in the financial crisis of the 2010s, during which he is credited with having saved the euro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Protesters Storm Iraqi Parliament
description: No lawmakers were present when the demonstrators, who were mostly followers of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, were in the building.
content: BAGHDAD — Hundreds of Iraqi protesters breached Baghdad’s Parliament on Wednesday, chanting anti-Iran curses in a demonstration against a nominee for prime minister chosen by Iran-backed parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta reports first revenue decline and a 36 percent profit drop.
description: It was the first time the social media giant’s revenue had fallen since it went public a decade ago, as it confronts increased regulatory scrutiny and a turbulent economy.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Facebook’s sales grew without fail and kept on growing, defying the laws of gravity even as the company was battered by scandals over privacy and misinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Are Your Summer Travel Questions?
description: Tell us and we’ll get some answers.
content: Travel this summer has been nightmarish at times, marred by delays, cancellations and other snags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Lufthansa Cancels Nearly All Flights in Frankfurt and Munich, Stranding 130,000 Travelers
description: The cancellations were announced after 3,000 employees walked off the job to protest for better wages.
content: Lufthansa Airlines canceled virtually all its flights in and out of Frankfurt and Munich on Wednesday, leaving more than 130,000 travelers scrambling, after around 3,000 employees walked off the job to protest for better wages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: The Life and Death of Daniel Auster, a Son of Literary Brooklyn
description: Memorably depicted in his father’s books, he struggled with drug addiction through a life that put him close to a notorious murder and came to an end in a family tragedy.
content: In a Brooklyn subway station one April morning, as commuters waited for a G train, a 44-year-old man named Daniel Auster was found unconscious on a platform after a drug overdose. He was brought to the Brooklyn Hospital Center, where he died six days later, after being taken off life support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: The Democratization of Airport Lounges
description: No longer just for the flying elite, these havens from chaos are easier to get into now, with the crowds to prove it.
content: When she has the time to get to the airport early, Anne Marie Mitchell, a communications professor in Chicago, will treat herself to a few hours in the airport lounge, either using a free pass from her airline credit card or paying a day-use fee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Insists There’s No Recession as He Confronts Latest Economic Risk
description: Officials have tried to ditch a shorthand definition for what constitutes a recession and reassure skeptical voters about the U.S. economy.
content: After a virtual meeting with tech manufacturing executives on Monday, President Biden was asked about his latest economic headache: How worried should Americans be that the country might be in a recession?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Behind the Story: The Plan to Save Yosemite by Cutting Down Trees
description: Times reporters explain why Yosemite officials champion a preservation plan that calls for chain saws.
content: In the 1860s, photos of Yosemite Valley taken by Carleton Watkins helped persuade President Abraham Lincoln to declare the land a protected public trust, a prelude to it becoming a national park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Katie Benner
title: The Fake Electors Scheme, Explained
description: The plan to reverse the outcome of the 2020 election by creating slates of electors pledged to Donald Trump in states he had lost was expansive, long-running and often confusing.
content: The brazen plan to create false slates of electors pledged to former President Donald J. Trump in seven swing states that were actually won by Joseph R. Biden Jr. was arguably the longest-running and most expansive of the multiple efforts by Mr. Trump and his allies to overturn the results of the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘We Met in Virtual Reality’ Review: Home Sweet Home
description: This innovative documentary tags along with people who are finding happiness in a graphical online world.
content: Joe Hunting’s “We Met in Virtual Reality” is the rare documentary shot entirely within an online world. It surveys the sort of space — specifically, a platform called VRChat — where people hang out “in person” as avatars of their choice. It’s a place of acceptance and social ease, and while it might not look as mind-bending as the fantasy realms portrayed in science fiction, it’s clearly no less liberating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In ‘Mr. Burns,’ Apocalypse Now, With ‘The Simpsons’ and Songs
description: Anne Washburn’s 2012 play about a post-pandemic society reckoning with loss has not aged at all, our critic writes.
content: Stories, like viruses, are transmissible. In the brain, in the blood, they mutate and change. Tragedies become comedies; dramas become myths. And in Anne Washburn’s visionary and wackadoo “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play,” revived by the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, an episode of “The Simpsons” becomes an opera and that opera becomes a way for a post-apocalyptic society to reckon with all it has lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Is High. How Will Rate Increases Fix That?
description: The Federal Reserve is raising interest rates to fight inflation. Some economists want more; some politicians want less. What’s the logic?
content: The Federal Reserve announced its fourth interest rate increase of 2022 on Wednesday as it races to tamp down rapid inflation. The moves have a lot of people wondering why rate increases — which raise the cost of borrowing money — are America’s main tool for cooling down prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
description: A summer of soul, and plenty of soul-searching, in this month’s nonfiction film selections.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Lear
title: On My 100th Birthday, Reflections on Archie Bunker and Donald Trump
description: The Emmy-winning TV producer Norman Lear considers his first century and his hopes for the next century.
content: Well, I made it. I am 100 years old today. I wake up every morning grateful to be alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Class Divisions Harden Into Battle Lines in Arizona’s Republican Primary
description: The race has highlighted the gap between G.O.P. voters who have profited from Arizona’s prosperity, and those who feel left out and are eager to punish the Republican establishment at the polls.
content: PRESCOTT VALLEY, Ariz. — As Shardé Walter’s family cut back on everything from camping trips to Eggo waffles to balance their inflation-strained budget this summer, she became more and more fed up with the Republicans who have governed Arizona for more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Hidden But Always Present
description: Enrique Henestroza Anguiano cleans out his closet.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hello, Wordplay readers! It is I, your faithful early-week crossword columnist, back from my cycling journey across the state of New York. And just in time to solve a puzzle by one of my favorite constructors! Today’s puzzle is by Enrique Henestroza Anguiano, a talented constructor and data scientist from the Bay Area.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Teen Witches to Critical Race Theory
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: VIOLET MADE OF THORNS, by Gina Chen. (Delacorte, $18.99, ages 14 and up.) A teenage witch lies about a prophecy and activates a looming curse on her kingdom’s prince, who happens to be both her enemy and the person she is falling in love with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Alex Lasry, a son of the Milwaukee Bucks’ co-owner, ends his Senate bid in Wisconsin.
description: The departure of Mr. Lasry, who largely self-funded his campaign to challenge Senator Ron Johnson, leaves the door open for Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes to win the Democratic nomination.
content: Alex Lasry, a Milwaukee Bucks executive who largely self-funded a Senate campaign in Wisconsin, dropped out of the Democratic primary on Wednesday, leaving Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes as the favorite for the nomination to face Senator Ron Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: Two Operas Conjure Apocalypses Personal and Cosmic
description: Romeo Castellucci directs, and Teodor Currentzis conducts, an unusual double bill of a Bartok classic and an Orff rarity at the Salzburg Festival.
content: SALZBURG, Austria — The public has spoken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Credit Suisse reports $1.65 billion loss for the second quarter as its European rivals see gains.
description: The Swiss bank’s weak performance stood in contrast to more upbeat reports from Deutsche Bank and UBS.
content: Credit Suisse slumped to a loss in the second quarter, it said on Wednesday, with results weighed down by its investment banking business. The Swiss bank also announced a change to its leadership and a shift to scale back the tarnished investment bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Tourist Jailed for Taking Artifacts in Iraq Has Conviction Overturned
description: A British retiree who had been sentenced to 15 years in prison for pocketing stones and shards at an archaeological site was acquitted on appeal.
content: A British tourist who was imprisoned for stealing ancient artifacts from an archaeological site has had his conviction overturned by an Iraqi court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford’s quarterly profit is up nearly 20% from a year earlier.
description: Overcoming the worst of a global chip shortage, the automaker sold more cars and trucks, and prices were higher.
content: Automakers are seeing improvements in the supply of computer chips, but shortages continue to disrupt production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
title: A Marauding Monkey Was Killed in Japan. Others Will Take Its Place.
description: As Japan’s macaque population grows, clashes with humans are becoming more frequent. More than 50 people were injured by recent monkey attacks in one western city.
content: TOKYO — The authorities in a western Japanese city said on Wednesday that they had killed a monkey they believe was responsible for a spate of attacks against humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: The Battle for Kherson
description: Ukraine hit a supply bridge in the Russian-held city while Moscow reinforced its positions.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Is the U.S. Economy Growing or Not?
description: One economic measure had it flailing. The other had it doing just fine.
content: They say a person with a wristwatch always knows what time it is but a person with two wristwatches is never quite sure. Which watch is telling the right time?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Carly Olson
title: Brittney Griner Describes Her Legal Ordeal to Russian Court
description: The W.N.B.A. star’s legal team has argued that have argued that the American basketball star did not intend to smuggle drugs into Russia.
content: Brittney Griner, the American basketball star detained in Russia on drug charges, told a courtroom Wednesday that she had been tossed into a bewildering legal system with little explanation of what was happening and what she might do to try to defend herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Errico
title: A ‘Girl Singer’ and Her Extra Hair Hit the Road
description: After a two-year hiatus, Melissa Errico is performing a slew of gigs honoring the composers Michel Legrand and Stephen Sondheim. As long as she gets to the airport (which airport again?) on time.
content: Alone in a Florida hotel room, I reach around the back of my (rented) red lace minidress. I find the zipper but can’t pull it up all the way. The dress is on right, I can see it in the mirror, but it’s gaping open. I do what every “girl singer” — as Stephen Sondheim called our kind, whatever our age — has learned to do on such occasions: I step into the hotel hallway, listen for voices and hope for the zipper-kindness of a stranger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Embraces LIV Golf, Backing a New Saudi Strategy
description: After decades of failure and rejection in sports, the former president’s New Jersey course will host a LIV Golf tournament this weekend, but the event is not simply about the golf.
content: Donald J. Trump has long toyed with becoming a sports baron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Extreme Weather Is Soaking New York City. Community Gardens Can Help.
description: Intense storms are on the rise, which probably means more flooding. Local green spaces are on the case.
content: The wooden shed in a community garden in northern Manhattan is not just for storing rakes, hoes and shovels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Hardly Anyone Talks About How Fracking Was an Extraordinary Boondoggle
description: There’s a lesson here on what big investments in clean energy could deliver.
content: In the energy scramble provoked by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, American liquid natural gas has so far played the role of Europe’s white knight. If Europe manages to keep its lights on, homes heated and factories running this winter, when energy demand is highest, it will be in large part thanks to shipments of American gas, which have more than doubled since the war began. Today, two-thirds of American oil and even more of its gas comes from hydraulic fracturing, better known as fracking, which has played this heroic-seeming role before, in the country’s long effort post-9/11 to get out from the grip of Middle Eastern producers and secure what is often described as “energy independence.” (Donald Trump preferred the term “energy dominance.”) It hasn’t proved quite as useful as you might think: Because energy prices are set on global markets, domestic production doesn’t mean Americans pay less at the pump. But thanks in large part to fracking, the United States has become the world’s largest producer of both oil and gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Spirit Airlines and Frontier call off a proposed merger.
description: The decision could improve prospects for Spirit to reach a deal with JetBlue, a suitor it had previously rejected.
content: A monthslong effort by Frontier Airlines to acquire Spirit Airlines abruptly ended on Wednesday when the companies called off their proposal, giving new life to a rival bid for Spirit by JetBlue Airways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Looming Question for Putin Opponents: Can You Change Russia From Jail?
description: For opposition figures choosing to stay in Russia after President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, imprisonment looks like a matter of time. It’s also a subject for fierce debate.
content: Shortly after Russia shocked the world by attacking Ukraine on Feb. 24, Ilya V. Yashin, a local Moscow councilman and prominent opposition figure, decided it was time to see a dentist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Is America Stuck in a Gerontocracy?
description: Michelle Cottle and David Brooks on what we really mean when we talk about age in politics.
content: American politics has an age problem. At least, that’s what voters think. According to a new New York Times/Siena College poll, 33 percent of Democrats who want a different candidate for president in 2024 pointed to Joe Biden’s age as a motivating factor. But a nearly equal percentage say they aren’t keen to have Biden for a second term because of his job performance — or lack thereof. Could the answer to appease voters be that Democrats just need some young blood? Or is there a deeper rift between voters — especially young ones — and political leadership?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: 3 Senate Hopefuls Denounce Big Tech. They Also Have Deep Ties to It.
description: Blake Masters, J.D. Vance and Mehmet Oz, all Republicans, have a history with the industry that involves uses of consumer data they now criticize.
content: For Republicans running for the Senate this year, “Big Tech” has become a catchall target, a phrase used to condemn the censorship of conservative voices on social media, invasions of privacy and the corruption of America’s youth — or all of the above.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Lourdes Grobet, Photographer of Mexico’s Masked Wrestlers, Dies at 81
description: In her innovative career, she found her ultimate subject in lucha libre wrestling: men and women who, to her, were members of an unexplored subculture.
content: Lourdes Grobet, whose father would not let her attend professional wrestling matches in Mexico because she was a girl, but who later become a photographer best known for her images of the body-slamming masked luchadores, both in the ring and in their everyday lives, died on July 15 at her home in Mexico City. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: The Japanese Author Behind ‘Bullet Train’ Is OK That the Film Isn’t So Japanese
description: Kotaro Isaka dreamed that his novel would get the big-screen treatment. Now it’s an action thriller starring Brad Pitt. Does the lack of major Asian stars matter?
content: SENDAI, Japan — Kotaro Isaka, one of Japan’s most popular crime thriller writers, is a self-described homebody. He rarely leaves Sendai, the city in northeast Japan where he lives, and many of his books are set there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Liz Cambage and the Los Angeles Sparks Agree to a ‘Divorce’
description: A four-time All-Star has another split with a W.N.B.A. team.
content: The four-time W.N.B.A. All-Star Liz Cambage and the Los Angeles Sparks are parting ways, the latest thorny ending for the star center who only three months ago confidently declared that the team was “where I want to be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey C. Kummer and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Last 2 Officers Involved in George Floyd’s Death Are Sentenced to Prison
description: A judge sentenced J. Alexander Kueng, who helped hold Mr. Floyd down, to three years in prison, and Tou Thao, who kept bystanders away, to three and a half years.
content: ST. PAUL, Minn. — A former Minneapolis police officer who kept bystanders away from George Floyd and another who helped pin Mr. Floyd down as he struggled to breathe were each sentenced to several years in prison on Wednesday, the last of the four officers involved in Mr. Floyd’s death to be ordered to prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Mike Isaac
title: F.T.C. Sues to Block Meta’s Virtual Reality Deal as It Confronts Big Tech
description: The move is a potential blow to Meta’s metaverse efforts and signals a shift in how the Federal Trade Commission is approaching tech deals.
content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday filed for an injunction to block Meta, the company formerly known as Facebook, from buying a virtual reality company called Within, potentially limiting the company’s push into the so-called metaverse and signaling a shift in how the agency is approaching tech deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Big Tech and the Fed
description: Some tech companies’ earnings are flagging, in what could be a positive sign for the Federal Reserve.
content: The long-booming bottom lines of major tech companies are all of a sudden smaller than expected. That might be a good thing. Big Tech sailed through the pandemic with its profits mostly intact. The fact that some firms’ results are now flagging could be a positive sign for the Federal Reserve, which is trying to engineer a slowdown as it fights the nation’s worst bout of inflation in four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Final ‘Jeopardy!’: Ken Jennings and Mayim Bialik to Split Hosting Duties
description: The popular game show, which has had trouble finding a new host since Alex Trebek died in 2020, will stick with the hosts who served temporarily this year.
content: For more than a year, there was one question that fans of “Jeopardy!” could never seem to get a clear answer to: Who would succeed its popular longtime host Alex Trebek after his death, becoming the new face of the popular quiz show?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: The Default Tech Settings You Should Turn Off Right Away
description: These controls, which are buried inside products from Apple, Google, Meta and others, make us share more data than we need to.
content: There’s a catchy saying going around with a valuable lesson about our personal technology: The devil is in the defaults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli and Ben Sisario
title: Is Beyoncé’s Latest Album Rollout (Gasp!) Conventional?
description: The singer, who has prioritized innovation over commercial domination, has opted for a more standard playbook ahead of her seventh solo album, “Renaissance,” out Friday.
content: An upbeat lead single ready for radio. An album title and release date with plenty of notice. A magazine cover story, followed by a personal mission statement, a fresh social media account, a detailed track list and a merchandise pre-sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Why Brandon Perea’s ‘Nope’ Audition Made Jordan Peele Cry
description: The actor’s unexpected take on Angel, the Fry’s worker, so won over the director that he decided during their meeting to rewrite the script.
content: When Brandon Perea was 15, touring the country as a professional dancer and roller skater, he had an epiphany in the parking lot of a Blue Coast Burrito: He would move from Chicago to Los Angeles to pursue his dream of becoming an actor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: U.S. to Distribute 800,000 Doses of Monkeypox Vaccine
description: The doses were withheld pending an F.D.A. review, which has now been completed.
content: Easing a shortfall that has plagued the fight against monkeypox for weeks, the Food and Drug Administration announced on Wednesday that it had cleared nearly 800,000 additional doses of vaccine for use. The Biden administration said it would announce allocations for states and jurisdictions on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What’s Wrong With Having Competitive Kids?
description: Nothing, unless they’re obnoxious about it.
content: My most repeated parental cliché is “everything is not a competition.” I say it at least once a day, when my children are doing something like racing down a path, jostling each other out of the way. It’s also a frequent refrain when one of my daughters declares that someone in her class is better at something than she is (long division, basketball, being taller). I usually add that if a skill is important to them and they want to improve, they need to work hard at it. My husband prefers the more poetic “comparison is the thief of joy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Assault Weapons Makers Testify They Bear No Responsibility for Gun Violence
description: A House panel found that the companies have thrived in the past decade by selling and marketing military-grade weapons to civilians, specifically young men.
content: WASHINGTON — Two top executives whose companies make the assault weapons that have been used to perpetrate some of the deadliest mass shootings in the country testified to Congress on Wednesday that they bore no responsibility for the surge in gun violence that has taken hold in the United States, even as their revenues from the sales of such weapons have soared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Tobacco Science Official Takes Job at Philip Morris
description: The agency official headed an office that plays a key role in deciding whether to approve e-cigarettes and other products aimed at reducing smoking.
content: A Food and Drug Administration official with considerable power over authorization decisions for e-cigarettes and products aimed at curbing smoking resigned on Tuesday to work for Philip Morris International, the global tobacco conglomerate and maker of Marlboros.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Julian E. Barnes and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: The U.S. has offered a prisoner swap to free Brittney Griner and another American, an official says.
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said Washington had offered to trade Viktor Bout and that he expected to raise it soon directly with Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken revealed on Wednesday that the United States had “put a substantial proposal on the table weeks ago” in talks with Russia to secure the release of the basketball star Brittney Griner and another detained American, Paul Whelan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy, Stanley Reed and Patrick Junker
title: Germany Counts on Chilled Gas to Keep Warm Over Winter
description: As Russia squeezes the flow of natural gas, German officials are urgently turning toward an option they had earlier disregarded: liquefied natural gas.
content: WILHELMSHAVEN, Germany — When a major energy company wanted to bring liquefied natural gas to Germany through the North Sea port of Wilhelmshaven three years ago, the proposal hit a brick wall. The company couldn’t find enough customers, the government offered only tepid support and residents denounced the scheme as a threat to a local apple orchard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Senate Passes Semiconductor Bill
description: Also, Japan struggles to curb monkey attacks and Hong Kong’s leaders embrace Xi Jinping.
content: In rare bipartisan fashion, the U.S. Senate passed an expansive $280 billion bill aimed at building up America’s manufacturing and technological edge to counter China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $425,000 Homes in North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Vermont
description: A 1917 farmhouse in Riegelwood, an 1812 rowhouse in Philadelphia and a two-bedroom bungalow in Manchester.
content: The owners of this house spent years returning it to its original state and chronicled the project on Instagram, where an account dedicated to the house has more than 65,000 followers. The work included restoring the hardwood floors and ceilings; adding new electric, plumbing and HVAC systems; repainting the exterior; and installing a new roof.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lizzo’s Complicated, Joyful Pop
description: The singer, rapper and songwriter’s peppy empowerment songs have made her an outlier in a field dominated by melancholic music.
content: Lizzo’s second major-label studio album, “Special,” another collection of up-tempo disco-pop empowerment anthems, just arrived at No. 2 on the Billboard album chart. Its single “About Damn Time” also climbed to No. 1 on the Hot 100, securing her place as one of pop’s established stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Have You Been Dealing With Extreme Weather in the U.S.?
description: We want to hear from you.
content: The Pacific Northwest, the part of the United States most unprepared for extreme heat, faces triple-digit temperatures this week. Flash floods swamped the St. Louis area, breaking a century-old rain record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Fox News snubbed Trump’s speech, in what’s becoming a pattern.
description: The network devoted little airtime to the speech on Tuesday by a former president its hosts often defend. Notably, it did go live with Mike Pence’s address.
content: When former President Donald J. Trump spoke to a friendly crowd on Tuesday in his first visit to Washington since leaving office, he was covered extensively by a range of news outlets, both mainstream ones and those more sympathetic to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Dept. Asking Witnesses About Trump in Its Jan. 6 Investigation
description: Federal prosecutors sought information about the former president’s role in the efforts to overturn the election as the inquiry accelerates.
content: Federal prosecutors have directly asked witnesses in recent days about former President Donald J. Trump’s involvement in efforts to reverse his election loss, a person familiar with the testimony said on Tuesday, suggesting that the Justice Department’s criminal investigation has moved into a more aggressive and politically fraught phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: The World’s Largest Hornet Is Getting a New Name
description: Scientists are hoping to reduce negative and nationalistic associations with the bee-slaying insect that is turning up in the Pacific Northwest.
content: It’s big. It’s bad. It will take off your head, eat your family and destroy your home. If you are a honeybee, that is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Study Finds Another Condition That Vitamin D Pills Do Not Help
description: The vitamin pills do not prevent bone fractures in most people or protect against many other diseases, adding to questions about medical guidance many now take for granted.
content: The idea made so much sense it was almost unquestioningly accepted: Vitamin D pills can protect bones from fractures. After all, the body needs the vitamin for the gut to absorb calcium, which bones need to grow and stay healthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: An Empathetic Account of the Complexity After Apartheid
description: In “The Inheritors,” Eve Fairbanks writes about South Africa’s racial reckoning through intimate portraits of those involved.
content: It was nothing short of a miracle — that was what South African schoolchildren were taught when Nelson Mandela was elected president in 1994, in the country’s first fully democratic elections. Apartheid, the brutal system of white minority rule that made South Africa a global pariah, was over. As Eve Fairbanks writes in “The Inheritors,” her new book about the decades before and after that transition, its miraculousness “was like mathematics, amazing but incontrovertible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Carlos Prieto, Clare Toeniskoetter, John Ketchum, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: How Deshaun Watson Became the N.F.L.’s Biggest Scandal
description: How one of the league’s biggest stars has become perhaps its biggest scandal.
content: This episode contains details of alleged sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Phyo Zeya Thaw, Burmese Pro-democracy Rapper, 41, Is Executed
description: The hip-hop star became a democracy activist in military-ruled Myanmar, and then a lawmaker. After the latest military coup, he joined the resistance, and was hanged for it.
content: U Phyo Zeya Thaw, a Burmese hip-hop pioneer whose democracy-affirming lyrics led to a career in Parliament and, after Myanmar’s military coup last year, as a resistance leader, was executed on Saturday in Yangon, Myanmar, by the country’s military junta. He was 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: At Yosemite, a Preservation Plan That Calls for Chain Saws
description: With treasured forests perennially threatened by fierce wildfires, many experts say it’s time to cut and burn protectively. A lawsuit is standing in the way.
content: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — The towering trees of Yosemite National Park have long held a treasured place in the American psyche, whether the ancient and majestic sequoias, the Ponderosa pines with their snake-patterned bark, or the acorn-laden black oaks, the lifeblood of many Native American cultures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Jim Tankersley and Lisa Friedman
title: Manchin, in Reversal, Agrees to Quick Action on Climate and Tax Plan
description: The West Virginia Democrat, a holdout on his party’s domestic agenda, said the package would reduce inflation, a concern he had cited in rejecting it just weeks ago.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a key centrist Democrat, announced on Wednesday that he had agreed to include hundreds of billions of dollars for climate and energy programs and tax increases in a package to subsidize health care and lower the cost of prescription drugs, less than two weeks after abruptly upending hopes for such an agreement this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Here are the takeaways from the Fed’s latest move.
description: The central bank made its second consecutive increase of three-quarters of a point as it tries to combat the fastest pace of inflation in 40 years.
content: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point on Wednesday, continuing its aggressive campaign to cool rapid inflation even as the economy begins to slow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colleen Stinchcombe
title: Go for a Float: A Beginner’s Guide to Stand-Up Paddling
description: The peaceful pastime is secretly a full-body workout. Here are a few techniques to keep in mind.
content: The first time Katie Vincent, 33, stood on a paddleboard, it was for a yoga class. The water at Green Lake in Seattle was frigid and surrounded by a walking path of gawking strangers. Rather than finding any kind of flow, Vincent fell into the water several times while other students were doing headstands.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Poor in Texas, and Helpless Against Heat
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 27, 2022.
content: “When you are poor, the sun finds you faster.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: On ‘Yellowstone’ and in Montana, the Same Question: Who Owns the West?
description: More Americans should live in the West, and more Americans will. But which ones?
content: In the most popular show on American television, “Yellowstone,” the heroes are the rich owners of a vast, gorgeous spread of Montana real estate. The villains are anyone else who wants to live there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Dormeshia Coasts on Her Tap Mastery in ‘Rhythm Is Life’
description: A jazz trio and three other dancers join Dormeshia for a classy, classic program filled with swing.
content: It comes as no surprise that “Rhythm Is Life,” the show that Dormeshia Tap Collective is presenting at the Joyce Theater this week, is a classy affair. The tap dancer Dormeshia is the epitome of elegance, and has been since she was a child. But she’s not just classy; she’s classical: so deeply versed in tap tradition and technique that she has the whole of it at her command and never has to worry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Passes $280 Billion Industrial Policy Bill to Counter China
description: The bipartisan vote reflected a rare consensus in the otherwise polarized Congress in favor of investing federal resources into a broad industrial policy to counter China.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday passed an expansive $280 billion bill aimed at building up America’s manufacturing and technological edge to counter China, embracing in an overwhelming bipartisan vote the most significant government intervention in industrial policy in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Reports Drop in Profit but Sees ‘Momentum’ for Turnaround
description: The company said it was close to restarting deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner plane and was on track to end the year with positive cash flow.
content: Boeing reported a drop in profit and weaker revenue than analysts had expected for the second quarter, but said on Wednesday that it was close to restarting deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner plane and was on track to end the year with more cash coming into the business than out of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Charap and Jeremy Shapiro
title: The U.S. and Russia Need to Start Talking Before It’s Too Late
description: Escalation, though incremental and thus far contained in Ukraine, is already underway.
content: In the five months since Russia launched its war in Ukraine, the United States has pledged about $24 billion in military aid to Ukraine. That’s more than four times Ukraine’s 2021 defense budget. America’s partners in Europe and beyond have pledged an additional $12 billion, according to the Kiel Institute for the World Economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Measuring America’s Divide: ‘It’s Gotten Worse’
description: Two scholars are trying to calculate just how polarized the United States has been over the past four decades — and how split it is now.
content: At a time of sporadic-but-disturbing episodes of political violence in America, of intense disputes over state and federal power and even of loose talk about the possibility of another civil war, is there any way to calculate how divided we are? Or do we just need to trust our gut?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Julian E. Barnes and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: U.S. Offers to Swap Russian Arms Dealer for Griner and Whelan
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he would speak to his Russian counterpart for the first time in months about a “substantial proposal” to free the Americans.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has offered to free the imprisoned Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout to secure the release of Brittney Griner and Paul N. Whelan, two Americans imprisoned in Russia who the State Department says were wrongfully detained, according to a person familiar with the negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: The E.U. agrees to cut gas use.
content: European Union energy ministers reached a deal yesterday to reduce their natural gas consumption by 15 percent, an effort to blunt Moscow’s ability to use energy as leverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Parents of Sandy Hook Victim at Alex Jones Trial Seek $150 Million in Damages
description: The figure represents the first time the family of a victim has put a dollar amount on the suffering Mr. Jones caused by spreading lies about the 2012 school shooting.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Lawyers for the parents of a child killed in the Sandy Hook school shooting told a jury here on Tuesday that the conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones should pay them $150 million for claiming that they were complicit in a government plot to fake the shooting as a pretext for gun control efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Like a Pile of Golden Retriever Puppies Drenched in Glitter
description: Our romance columnist found much to like in the latest crop of summer novels.
content: Romance has been up to its elbow-length gloves in inheritance problems since Longbourn was first entailed. Aristocratic titles, family fortunes and wills with unlikely marriage requirements are standard plot mechanisms by now, and they’re all over this month’s romances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Language Changed
description: Digital media is changing language — sometimes rapidly. We explore the example of American Sign Language.
content: On a train ride from New York to Connecticut last fall, my colleague Amanda Morris and her mother were having a conversation in American Sign Language. A man sitting near them saw them signing to each other and decided to join their conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: For France, All or Nothing Yields the Latter Again
description: Coach Corinne Diacre set a high bar for France at the Euros. But tying one’s fate to results works only when they’re good.
content: ROTHERHAM, England — Corinne Diacre punched the air, allowed herself a cursory smile of satisfaction, and then turned on her heel. She managed to dodge the first couple of staff members rushing past her on their way to join the celebrations on the field after France’s quarterfinal victory, only to find her path blocked by Gilles Fouache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Oregon Residents Help Officials Arrest Man Accused of Starting Wildfires
description: Three residents of Curry County, Ore., spotted the man and, after a struggle, tied him to a tree until law enforcement officers arrived, the authorities said.
content: A man wanted on charges that he started two wildfires in rural Oregon on Monday was spotted walking along a roadway by three local residents who, after a struggle, tied him to a tree until law enforcement officers arrived, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Where the Covid Outbreak Began
description: Two studies are giving us insight into the roots of the pandemic.
content: Two studies published yesterday in Science magazine are giving us insight into the roots of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Wembi and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Anti-U.N. Protests in Congo Leave 15 Dead, Including 3 Peacekeepers
description: Demonstrators have accused international forces of failing to deter armed groups responsible for a wave of deadly attacks.
content: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — At least 15 people, including three U.N. peacekeepers, have been killed and 60 others injured in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, in an escalation of dayslong protests against the United Nations in a mineral-rich region that has been ravaged by incessant deadly violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Caldwell
title: Stroudsburg, Pa.: A Small Town at the ‘Heart of the Poconos’
description: The Monroe County borough has been welcoming city dwellers since long before the pandemic: “People come here and discover a new world.”
content: A little over a year ago, Charise Miller’s commute to work increased — a lot. It now takes her about an hour and a half to get to her office in New York City, instead of 10 minutes. But she’s fine with that, because it means she doesn’t have to spend two hours finding a parking space after work, as she did when she lived in the Bronx, near Yankee Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: H.I.V. Infections Remain Persistently High, U.N. Reports
description: More than 1.5 million people worldwide, many of them young girls, were infected amid pandemic disruptions in 2021.
content: While the world’s attention was riveted on the Covid pandemic and the war in Ukraine, the fight against an older foe lost crucial ground: More than 1.5 million people became infected with H.I.V. last year, roughly three times the global target, the United Nations reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 145 Picture Prompts to Inspire Student Writing
description: A school year’s worth of short, accessible image-driven posts that invite a variety of kinds of writing.
content: We’ve been publishing our Picture Prompts series four days a week since 2016. Below, we’ve rounded up all the prompts we published for the 2021-22 school year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Kaiser-Schatzlein
title: Alabama Takes From the Poor and Gives to the Rich
description: How fines and fees trap people in a kind of penury from which they may never escape.
content: In states like Alabama, almost every interaction a person has with the criminal justice system comes with a financial cost. If you’re assigned to a pretrial program to reduce your sentence, each class attended incurs a fee. If you’re on probation, you’ll pay a fee to take your mandatory urine test. If you appear in drug court, you will face more fees, sometimes dozens of times a year. Often, you don’t even have to break the law; you’ll pay fees to pull a public record or apply for a permit. For poor people, this system is a trap, sucking them into a cycle of sometimes unpayable debt that constrains their lives and almost guarantees financial hardship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Early Europeans Could Not Tolerate Milk but Drank It Anyway, Study Finds
description: For thousands of years, Europeans consumed milk products despite lacking an enzyme needed to avoid gastrointestinal discomfort, according to a new study.
content: In many ways, humans are weird mammals. And our relationship with milk is especially weird.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Can Democrats Avoid a Midterm Wipeout?
description: The upcoming election season might be more competitive than predicted.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Man Accused in Jan. 6 Assault on Officer Pleads Guilty to Lesser Charges
description: George Tanios was initially charged with helping to attack Officer Brian Sicknick with chemical spray, but pleaded guilty to misdemeanors under a deal with prosecutors.
content: A West Virginia man who was charged last year with taking part in a high-profile assault on Officer Brian D. Sicknick during the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol pleaded guilty on Wednesday to two misdemeanor charges after reaching a deal with federal prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez and Mike Ives
title: Strong Quake Hits Northern Philippines, Killing at Least 4
description: The 7.0 magnitude quake on Luzon island damaged buildings and caused dozens of landslides, officials said. At least 44 people were hurt.
content: MANILA — A strong earthquake hit the northern Philippines on Wednesday morning, killing at least four people, causing dozens of landslides and severely damaging buildings, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: Sometimes an Improvised Sauce Is the Best Sauce
description: This recipe for bright and summery citrus-chile fish is just a starting point for your own brilliant creation.
content: When I pick up a knife, my husband is not nervous, not really. He keeps an eye out. He hovers. Finally, he can’t help himself: He reaches over and gently adjusts my guiding hand, making sure the fingers are curled properly and only the knuckles face the blade, so I won’t cut myself as I slice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Will Send More Helicopters to Mars
description: Instead of sending another rover to help retrieve rock and dirt samples from the red planet and bring them to Earth, the agency will provide the helicopters as a backup option.
content: The first helicopter that NASA sent to Mars worked so well that it is sending two more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Is Trump in Legal Peril? This Ex-Prosecutor Would Know
description: One of the last federal prosecutors to lead an investigation into Donald Trump discussed the challenges of bringing charges against him in the Jan. 6 case.
content: The biggest question set off by the special committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol attack has been: Will the Justice Department prosecute former President Donald J. Trump for his role in trying to overturn the election? The question has become even more prominent with the news that federal prosecutors have begun asking witnesses about Mr. Trump in their criminal investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Laura Boushnak
title: Nightlife is returning to Ukraine’s capital. But revelers have to reckon with guilt, and a curfew.
description: KYIV, Ukraine — The rave had been planned for weeks, with the space secured and the D.J.s, the drinks, the invites and the security all lined up.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The rave had been planned for weeks, with the space secured and the D.J.s, the drinks, the invites and the security all lined up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Emily Erdos and Kelsey McClellan
title: How Bacon and Costco Fish Shape America’s View of Inflation
description: Economic policymakers are razor focused on inflation expectations after more than a year of rapid price increases. Consumers explain how they’re thinking about rising costs.
content: Inflation started in the bacon aisle for Dan Burnett, a 58-year-old former medical center administrator who lives in Margaretville, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: House Hunting in Bahrain: Gulf Views From a Fish-Shaped Isle for $1 Million
description: Despite rapid population growth and an influx of foreigners, Bahrain has seen a softening residential market due to an oversupply of housing.
content: This three-bedroom waterfront villa sits on an artificial island in the Persian Gulf, part of a massive resort development called Durrat Al Bahrain, off the southeastern tip of Bahrain Island, the largest island in the archipelago of Bahrain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Kaiser-Schatzlein
title: Why Does the Prison-Life Content on TikTok Feel So Familiar?
description: Cooking, life advice, bored dancing, workout tips — on social media, you’re reminded that incarceration is a pretty common slice of American life.
content: In a recent video on TikTok, a suburban-looking mom called Marci Marie walks into a suburban-looking kitchen. She has bleached-blond hair, a kind smile, sparkling eyes and a warm Texan accent. “Hey y’all,” she says. “Today I want to show you guys how we made pizza in the penitentiary.” She produces a bowl and begins. “The trickiest part,” she says, “is getting your sauce right.” She starts with ketchup as a base, adds a little V8 juice and then thickens the mix with crushed potato chips. “Guys, the seasoning is the key,” she says, adding garlic powder and minced onion. Next comes the dough, made by shredding slices of white bread into a potato-chip bag and tipping in a little water. She works the bag with her hands, then unfurls it and pats the dough into a flat circle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Is a Fan of Pope Francis
description: “He’s reached out to other faiths, he said gay people can get into heaven, and don’t forget he added a pop and lock to the sign of the cross,” Noah joked on Tuesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Berkshire Hathaway-owned lender to pay $20 million in redlining case.
description: Trident Mortgage discouraged minorities in Philadelphia from applying for home loans, the authorities say.
content: The mortgage lender Trident Mortgage, owned by Berkshire Hathaway, has agreed to pay $20 million to settle state and federal prosecutors’ allegations that it worked to keep people in nonwhite neighborhoods in and around Philadelphia from applying for home loans, according to an announcement by the prosecutors on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: For Hong Kong’s Beijing-Backed Officials, Xi’s All That
description: The city’s leaders are rushing to embrace Xi Jinping, China’s leader, a performance of devotion that is a jarring shift for Hong Kong’s once rambunctious political culture.
content: HONG KONG — On his first full day on the job, Hong Kong’s new leader, John Lee, shared a picture of himself working at his desk with a printout of what he described as an important speech by Xi Jinping, China’s leader, placed next to his notebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: Senior European Parliament Member Targeted as Spyware Abuse Spreads
description: The attempted hack of a Greek opposition leader is the first aimed at a European Parliament member to be detected, but he has plenty of company among politicians, journalists and dissidents.
content: BRUSSELS — As the number of politicians, activists and journalists hacked with spyware grew to include prime ministers and prominent dissidents in the European Union, the world’s biggest democratic club, the European Parliament in April started checking its members’ phones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
title: With Roe Gone, Republicans Quarrel Over How Far to Push Abortion Bans
description: An effort in Indiana to pass an abortion ban with exceptions has exposed rifts among conservatives on how to legislate in a post-Roe world.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Abortion opponents, especially in conservative states, had hoped to swiftly pass a new wave of restrictions after Roe v. Wade was overturned. But so far, most Republican lawmakers have moved cautiously or done nothing at all, even in statehouses where they hold overwhelming majorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Russia Cuts Natural Gas Flow to Germany Yet Again
description: Gazprom, the Russian energy giant, blamed equipment made by Siemens Energy, a German company, for the cuts to pipeline flows, prompting a sharp response.
content: Gazprom, the Russian energy giant, followed through on Wednesday with its announcement earlier this week that it would further restrict the flows of natural gas to Germany and other European countries through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline. It also blamed Siemens Energy, the German maker of turbines used on the pipeline, for causing the cutbacks, prompting a sharp retort from the company.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Find the One
description: After swooning at the interracial couple in “Bend It Like Beckham,” she knew how she wanted her romantic life to unfold. But the future had other plans.
content: [What’s the most unusual place you have ever gone on a date? Tell us your story, and you may be featured in a future episode. Visit nytimes.com/datestory for submission details.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: He Ordered Celebrities’ Absentee Ballots. Now He’s Under Arrest.
description: A criminal complaint filed in Federal District Court claimed that Louis Koch obtained the absentee ballots of public figures, calling the practice a “hobby.”
content: Two years ago, a Manhattan resident, Louis Koch, asked the New York City Board of Elections to mail him absentee ballots for the primary and general elections for 2020, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Red and Blue America Will Never Be the Same
description: There are long-term trends for both parties to be happy about.
content: Donald Trump’s dominance of the political stage for the past seven years galvanized what had been a slow-burning realignment, creating a profound upheaval in the electorate and in both the Democratic and Republican parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Federal Reserve Makes Another Supersized Rate Increase to Tame Inflation
description: The central bank raised rates by three-quarters of a percentage point and suggested additional large increases could be warranted.
content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve continued its campaign of rapid interest rate increases on Wednesday, pushing up borrowing costs at the fastest pace in decades in an effort to wrestle inflation under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Tests Negative for Covid and Will End Isolation
description: The president’s symptoms are “almost completely resolved,” his physician said, but he will continue to wear a mask and test more frequently than usual in coming days.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden returned to the Oval Office with a triumphant flair on Wednesday after testing negative for Covid-19, boasting that his mild case was evidence of the progress his administration had made in stemming the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Special Military Cell Flows Weapons and Equipment Into Ukraine
description: A little-known group at U.S. European Command in Germany fills Ukraine’s battlefield requests with donations from more than 40 countries.
content: STUTTGART, Germany — It takes a village to help Ukraine fight the Russians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Schneider
title: James Lovelock, Whose Gaia Theory Saw the Earth as Alive, Dies at 103
description: A British ecologist, he captured imaginations with his hypothesis and was essential to today’s understanding of man-made pollutants and their effect on the climate.
content: James Lovelock, the maverick British ecologist whose work was essential to today’s understanding of man-made pollutants and their effect on climate and who captured the scientific world’s imagination with his Gaia theory, portraying the Earth as a living creature, died on Tuesday, his 103rd birthday, at his home in Dorset, in southwest England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur and Monique Jaques
title: For Women’s Cyclists, It’s a Steep Climb to Tour Equality
description: A women’s Tour de France is back after 33 years — a sign of progress, contestants say, for a sport sorely in need of it.
content: MEAUX, France — After winning Stage 2 of the Tour de France Femmes, the Dutch cyclist Marianne Vos pulled on the Tour leader’s yellow jersey for the first time and explained that no, actually, this special moment was not something that had always been a dream for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Why Do LIV Golfers Struggle to Explain Why They Left the PGA Tour?
description: The latest golfers to join the Saudi-backed series were vague and defensive in the face of hard questions about guaranteed money and human-rights issues.
content: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — Last month, Justin Thomas, the world’s seventh-ranked men’s golfer, summed up the feelings of PGA Tour players like himself who have rejected the sumptuous money offers of the rival, Saudi-backed LIV Golf series to remain with the established tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Is Facing Crisis After Crisis. But Are They Emergencies?
description: President Biden is under pressure — often from his own allies — to declare national emergencies on issues like climate and abortion that are roiling American culture.
content: WASHINGTON — In a time of political and economic turmoil, just what, exactly, counts as a national emergency?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Ford and Mellon Foundations Announce 2022 Disability Futures Fellows
description: A Broadway actress, documentary filmmaker and DC comic artist are among this year’s recipients. They were selected by fellow disabled artists from a pool of about 60 nominees.
content: Nasreen Alkhateeb, a filmmaker who has documented Kamala Harris on the campaign trail; Antoine Hunter, also known as Purple Fire Crow, a Deaf, Indigenous choreographer whose work has been performed around the world; and Tee Franklin, who is writing new Harley Quinn comics for DC, are among the second class of disability futures fellows, the Ford and Andrew W. Mellon Foundations announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: ‘Into the Woods’ and a Missing Giant’s Boot
description: When the Stephen Sondheim musical opened in 1987, a huge boot hung over the theater’s facade. The producers of the current revival would love to get it back.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Scroll down for a look at when a plane smashed into the Empire State Building — 77 years ago today. But first, a Broadway mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: The Joyce Theater Announces a Debut-Packed Season
description: The fall-winter season will include international groups, as well as performances by Alan Cumming, Camille A. Brown and others.
content: After a total of 72 weeks of canceled programming since March 2020, including sporadic cancellations this spring, the Joyce Theater will present its annual 22-week fall season, with renewed hopes to run each and every scheduled performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Ukraine hits a key bridge in Kherson as Russia steps up missile strikes across the south.
description: The bridge is a critical part of Russia’s resupply route for the forces charged with holding the port city.
content: Explosions lit up the sky over the southern city of Kherson overnight, and as dawn broke on Wednesday it was clear that Ukrainian long-range missiles had once again found their target: a bridge that is critical in the Russian effort to resupply the forces charged with holding the port city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Irma Vep’ and More
description: I’m a pop music reporter on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching and reading.
content: I’m a pop music reporter on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching and reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abrahm Lustgarten
title: The Barbados Rebellion: An Island Nation’s Fight for Climate Justice
description: The Caribbean is trapped between crushing debt and a climate disaster caused by rich nations. Prime Minister Mia Mottley is battling for a fairer system.
content: The Caribbean is trapped between crushing debt and a climate disaster caused by rich nations. Prime Minister Mia Mottley is battling for a fairer system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living in ... Stroudsburg, Pa.
description: The Monroe County borough has been welcoming city dwellers since long before the pandemic: “People come here and discover a new world.”
content: The Monroe County borough has been welcoming city dwellers since long before the pandemic: “People come here and discover a new world.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $425,000
description: A 1917 farmhouse in Riegelwood, N.C.; an 1812 rowhouse in Philadelphia; and a two-bedroom bungalow in Manchester, Vt.
content: A 1917 farmhouse in Riegelwood, N.C.; an 1812 rowhouse in Philadelphia; and a two-bedroom bungalow in Manchester, Vt.

title: Federal Reserve Raises Interest Rate for the Fourth Time in 2022

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Ends Isolation After Testing Negative for Covid
description: President Biden urged Americans to get booster shots, use at-home test kits and take antiviral drug treatments to fight the coronavirus.
content: President Biden urged Americans to get booster shots, use at-home test kits and take antiviral drug treatments to fight the coronavirus.

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Protesters Storm Iraqi Parliament Over Prime Minister Nominee
description: Hundreds of supporters of the Iraqi Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr breached the Iraqi Parliament in a demonstration against a nominee for prime minister chosen by Iran-backed parties.
content: Hundreds of supporters of the Iraqi Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr breached the Iraqi Parliament in a demonstration against a nominee for prime minister chosen by Iran-backed parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Opam
title: Podcasts About Marvel’s ‘X-Men’ Resonate With L.G.B.T.Q. Fans
description: A community of “X-Men” fans — notably young, self-identified queer people of color — is growing around podcasts and on social platforms including Twitter, TikTok and Discord.
content: In the world of podcasts about “X-Men,” flitting from allegories for inequity to “The Real Housewives” is almost effortless.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 27, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 27, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Russia’s decision to reduce gas deliveries to Germany misstated the sea under which the Nord Stream 1 pipeline runs. It is the Baltic Sea, not the North Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Work Friends Can Last a Lifetime

content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Recipes for Any Temperature
description: A cooling chicken salad if it’s hot, poached fish if it’s cold, and pressure-cooker pork belly no matter the weather.
content: Good morning. The punishing heat continues where I stay. While I’m turning on the stove occasionally, my meals are mostly running no-cook and salad-adjacent: say, marinated celery salad with chickpeas and Parmesan or, in the same vein, marinated zucchini with farro, chickpeas and Parmesan. Who wants to labor over a burner when you could eat delicious cooling food instead?
source.name: The New York Times
